bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lindsley Arthur, April 15, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] answers Arthur's questions regarding mosquitos and their relationship to malaria and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lindsley Arthur, April 15, 1923
div1.opener:
N. M. C
Chara
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
April 15, 1923.
Mr. Lindsley Arthur,
Malaria Field Agent,
Georgetown County Malarial Control,
P. O. Box 358, Georgetown, S. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I am engaged on a work at present, which rarely leaves me an extra
half hour even that I can devote to anything else and if your questions
were not about malaria I would simply express inability to answer your
letter.

1/ In the only edition of the primer I have, that revised April /18,
I see no mention made of plants which attack the life of the adult mos-
quito, nor do I recollect any that do so efficiently. Castor oil beans
were supposed to have this effect, but I think it doubtful.

Quite a number of water plants affect the breeding of Anopheles.
Most of them unfortunately increase breeding by the protection they give
larvae against fish. My recollection is that I said something about
this at the last meeting of the National Malaria Committee. If I did,
and it is published, I will let you know how to get it.

Of these plants that lessen breeding the common “duck weed,” where
thick enough to cover the water does this mechanically and is exten-
sively used for this purpose in Southern Europe. There is reason to be-
lieve that some others prevent breeding by the chemicals they exhude to
the water: among them the “water pepper,” and possibly the white-flowered
“arrow leaf.” I have not time to go into this. You might try the “duck
weed” and note whether you find any breeding among the “arrow leaf.” Both
grow in your section.

The latest candidates for this function are the different species of
Chara--especially Chara foetida, which Howard, Chief of the Bureau of
Entomology, is now investigating. I will send you in this some notes from
from
-2-
a foreign journal which should be of interest, and may be of use to you.
If you can, I wish you would pass them on to Fisher.

You have seen Coogle's use of creosote, or rather cresol, as a re-
pellent of adult mosquitoes. It is in a late number of the U. S. Pub-
lic Health Reports, which I have no doubt you get. It promises to be
valuable, especially among the negro cabins in the South.

2/ I profoundly doubt if there be “numbers of people” in the County,
who cannot take quinine. Of something over 150,000 people in Panama, only
three were found with idiosyncrasies to quinine, though probably over 1/2
said they had it. Quinine immunization is a make-shift at best, only to
be used until more efficient methods can be instituted. Quinine is best
given in one dose per day after supper or on going to bed.

3/ The males of all mosquitoes feed on honey and other juices and,
some of them at least, on pollen of flowers.

4/ Do not know why the Culex and Stegomyia are not carriers of the
malaria parasites. Some species of Anopheles, as you know, do not carry
them.

5/ I cannot discuss haemoglobinuric fever. It would take too much
time: Only the same measures that control all malarial fever have, in
other places, eliminated it also.

I am glad you like the malarial catechism. It is the joint product
of my daughter and myself.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General. Enclosure.
